title: The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: A small river, or rather a mountain torrent, called theTalla, breaks down the glen with great fury, dashing successively over anumber of small cascades, which has procured the spot the name of TallaLinns.

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Bid him come hither to our aid," she said, "andbring with him his lambs, as he calls them--Bowton, Hay of Talla, BlackOrmiston, and his kinsman Hob--Fie! how swart they are, and how theysmell of sulphur! What! closeted with Morton?

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Third, and above all, for the utter fatigue into which I fell just pastthe crossing of Talla.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: So ye maun be aff, and I counsel yeto tak the taps o' the Wormel and syne cross the water abune the Crook,and gang ower by Talla and Fruid to the Cor.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Iminded how I had heard of the son of Lord Fairley, a great soldier whohad won high renown in the wars abroad: and how he had returned amelancholy man, weighed down with the grave cares of religion, and goneto the wilds of Tweed to a hut just above the Linns of Talla, where hespent his days in prayer and meditation.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Far to the right, where the Talla joinsthe Tweed, we could mark the few lights of the little village ofTweedsmuir.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: We were now descending a steep hillside, all rough with _sklidders_, andcoming to the Water of Talla, which we forded at a shallow a littlebelow the wild waterfall called Talla Linns.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Then why, since " utpkturapoesis" be ofiended by the description  of North more than of Poussin ? Homelier, indeed, are the names and the natures of his bathing beauties ; yet chastity  is the virtue by which Scotia's shepherdesses are guarded and adorned ; and the waters of the Talla, are they not as pure as those of the Ilissus ?

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Gay, gamesome streamlet, that comes dancing into the Tweed from Talla Linns, let me follow up thy murmurs for a mile or so, and, by way of a finale, take a bathe in the Silver Pool, so named by shepherds for its perpetual pellucidity.

title: Essays critical and imaginative,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Then why, since " utpicturapoesis" be offended by the description  of North more than of Poussin ? Homelier, indeed, are the names and the natures of his bathing beauties ; yet chastity  is the virtue by which Scotia's shepherdesses are guarded and adorned ; and the waters of the Talla, are they not as pure as those of the Ilissus ?

title: Essays critical and imaginative,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: We felt it was indeed time to "gang our wa's; " for Girzie, as she was growing more and more impassioned in her beseeching, rose higher and higher from the water, and stood nearly to the waist unveiled, the long-sought Naiad of the Silver Pool of Talla.
